name: 4ocean
text: @AprilBondurant At our Bali, Haiti, and Guatemala locations, we are storing what can't be recycled while evaluating our co-processing options in those locations. (3/3)

name: 4ocean
text: @AprilBondurant At our South Florida location, everything we can't recycle is taken to Solid Waste Authority (the lowest emission facility in the country) where it is turned into energy. (2/3)

name: 4ocean
text: @AprilBondurant Great question! Everything we collect is brought back to our facility where it is carefully sorted and weighed. What we can recycle gets recycled either by us for use in current and future products, or with local recycling partners in each community. (1/3)

name: 4ocean
text: At 4ocean, we are working hard every day to increase the amount of reclaimed ocean plastic used in our products. Stay tuned for future announcements about new products in our pipeline!

name: 4ocean
text: The glass beads in our bracelets are manufactured in China from 95% certified post-consumer recycled glass, including less than 5% reclaimed ocean glass. The 40 charm is made from recycled stainless steel.

name: 4ocean
text: Each bracelet is hand-assembled in Bali by a team of skilled artisans from the local community. The cord in our bracelets is manufactured in China from 100% certified post-consumer recycled plastic including less than 5% reclaimed ocean plastic.

name: 4ocean
text: We thought it was important to have this evaluation process done back in 2018 so our consumers can feel comfortable knowing that our bracelets are made from recycled materials and do, in fact, include reclaimed ocean plastic and glass.

name: 4ocean
text: To date, we have removed 8,691,089 pounds of trash from the oceans and coastlines and we‚Äôre not stopping anytime soon. We have cleanup operations in Bali, Haiti, Guatemala, and Florida. #4ocean #plasticfree #breakfreefromplastic

name: 4ocean
text: 6. The trash filled sacks are then transported back to the cleanup operation base where the plastic can be sorted and stored for future use in products or be responsibly recycled. https://t.co/cocm83CO3A

name: 4ocean
text: 5. The sacks are weighed. This is documented by photo and a log sheet. The sheet contains date, time spent cleaning, number of crew working, weight of each sack, total weight collected, and dual authorization signature from the recorder and administrator. https://t.co/1YLnEj4tKk

name: 4ocean
text:
3. The crew then gets to work. Throughout the cleanup, they document the operation with photos and video (if applicable). All trash is placed into sacks for storage and future weighing.
4. Once the cleanup is completed, the crew documents the impact area again.

name: 4ocean
text:
1. The crew arrives early in the morning because most impact areas take several hours (sometimes days) to clean.

2. Upon arrival, the crew will document the impact area (prior to cleanup) with a photo. https://t.co/6YCvThWDT5

name: 4ocean

More than 8 million tons of plastic ends up in the ocean every year. Most of this plastic is washed into the ocean by rivers. The top polluting rivers all have two things in common; a high population living around them and a poor waste management system.

name: 4ocean
text: @hwriteandrevise @plasticmakers We agree that it's more than just cleanups that are required. That is why it is our mission to cleanup the plastic that already exists in the ocean as well as influence individuals, brands, and companies to change their plastic consumption habits.

name: 4ocean

name: 4ocean
text: @MandaLynneArt @balloonslovelys There are two types of materials that balloons are generally made from-- mylar and latex. The mylar balloons are usually a mylar nylon which is a stretched polyester film, a specific type of plastic. These balloons do not break down in the environment and are not recyclable.

text: @Ferdinand3030 It‚Äôs estimated that about 80% of the trash in the ocean comes from land-based sources. This is due to both natural causes (such as storms, tsunamis) and also man-made causes like littering, overflowing trash cans, or bad disposal practices by waste facilities.

text: @GennyMarie7 It's important to understand that plastic pollution is a complex problem that goes far beyond littering. name: 4ocean
text: @Ra_deTizi Some plastics float in seawater, others sink and some remain neutrally buoyant. Density is one factor that affects the buoyancy of plastic debris. If plastic is denser than seawater, it will sink. If it‚Äôs less dense, it will float. (1/2)
